newsitem.title: UK: Nobel winner says UK tax rates could be higher.
newsitem.headline: Nobel winner says UK tax rates could be higher.

text.p: British professor James Mirrlees, joint winner of the Nobel prize for Economics, said on Tuesday he believed tax rates in Britain could be higher.
Mirrlees, speaking to Reuters after his work on tax incentives won international recognition, said: "Tax rates in this country could reasonably be higher, particularly for middle income earners."

He put the average level of income tax and VAT combined at less than 50 percent. "I think it could well go above. It would become a disincentive but you could use the revenue for health services, education and welfare payments," he said.

Mirrless and Canadian William Vickrey won the 1996 Nobel Economics Prize for what the academy said was "their fundamental contributions to the economic theory of incentives under asymmetric information."
